Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Effects of Prolonged Droughts, Severe Fires, and Forest Parasites on Regional Ecosystem Pattern in the Rocky Mountains Over the Past 5,000 Years

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change is an ongoing outcome of human activity. Regions such as the Rocky Mountains have already experienced significant warming in the past decade. The warming has reduced snowpack and related runoff, facilitated extensive forest damage from insects and other pathogens, and increased areas burned by wildfires. Such effects on water and ecosystems are likely to generate substantial societal challenges for decades or longer, but are poorly understood and hard to predict. Characterizing past climate changes and their impacts provides a means to place such regional changes in a long-term context and to anticipate how such impacts on ecosystems and the goods and services they produce will continue to develop in the future. This project focuses on the role of disturbances (i.e., fires and forest-parasite infestations) in mediating vegetation responses to persistent droughts over the past 5000 years. The goal is to document the types of interactions and regional differences that can influence regional responses to climate change. To do so, the project will study sediments from six lakes in the Park Range of northern Colorado, which were chosen to represent different aspects of the region. Sedimentary evidence of episodes of low lakes-levels in the past will be used to document past droughts, and then will be compared with fossil evidence of vegetation change, forest fires, and forest-parasite outbreaks to document possible climate-disturbance-vegetation interactions and their spatial patterns. Two lakes are located at the lower margins of the range near the border between pine forests and sagebrush steppe, two are within dense pine forests at mid-elevations, and two are within open forest parklands at high elevations along the Continental Divide. The results will show how the lower border between forest and steppe was shifted through time by drought, fire, and parasites, and how the density of forest cover at mid- and high-elevations affected the sensitivity of fire regimes, and thus forest composition, to climate change.

Climate change is altering the patterns of ecosystems from local to continental scales. Because changes in precipitation, vegetation, and fire regimes in the Rocky Mountains during the past decade have been dramatic, the project will document these recent changes with repeat photography, and then place the changes in a long-term context via studies of ancient climate changes and their impacts on the forested landscape. To enhance public understanding of climate change impacts, the results of the study will be displayed and explained in an on-line atlas of environmental change in the Rockies along with photography of the ongoing changes in the region (using new photos as well as others taken more than ten years ago). The photos and other results will be made available through a web-based atlas of environmental change in the region, which will be designed to aid K-12 teachers in understanding and explaining the geography and potential outcomes of climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bryan Shuman, a professor at the University of Wyoming, has worked with a team of students to study the impacts of droughts and wildfire on forests in the Rocky Mountains using fossil material spanning millennia. The studies were supported by an NSF CAREER grant, “Effects of Prolonged Droughts, Severe Fires, and Forest Parasites on Regional Ecosystem Pattern in the Rocky Mountains over the Past 5000 Years.” The award supported the dissertation of 2016 Ph.D. graduate, John Calder, as well as opportunities for twenty other undergraduate and graduate students to participate in research aimed at critical forest and water resources.

The projects provide a long-term perspective on how forests in the Rocky Mountains, and elsewhere, change when affected by events like the recent mountain pine beetle outbreak that has devastated many forests of the western U.S. over the past decade. Because fossil material such as microscopic pollen and fragments of charcoal wash into lakes and remain preserved in layers of mud at the lake bottom for millennia, Shuman, Calder, and others were able to collect cores from lakes that retained the history of the forests of northern Colorado. Because lakes also rise and fall during wet periods and droughts, the research team was able to use geological evidence to evaluate past changes in water supplies that played out over many centuries or thousands of years.

The studies showed that the Rocky Mountain region is currently wetter than it has been for most of the period since the last ice age. Extended droughts and persistent severe aridity that reduced snowpack, surface and groundwater levels, and streamflow were more often the norm than the current historic range of conditions. The changes in water supply as well as regional temperature changes that Shuman and his team have reconstructed help to explain why the archeological record from Wyoming includes long periods with little evidence of human occupation of the region, especially about 8000-6000 years ago. These periods were the warmest and driest since human’s first arrived over 13,000 years ago.

Surprisingly, however, Shuman and colleagues found that some sub-alpine forests persisted through such changes and remained remarkably stable for many millennia. Wildfires, however, burned larger portions of the landscape during past periods than during the historic interval since the late 1800s. In any given century, fires typically burn only about ~40% of the forests spread over a mountain range like the Mount Zirkel Wilderness of northern Colorado where most of the research was conducted. However, during the Medieval Period about 1000 years ago, drought and high temperatures caused >80% of Calder’s study site to burn, which would be equal to having large fires, like Colorado’s historically-large fires of the last decade, burn in that landscape once per decade for the next century. The Medieval fires indicate a high risk of large severe fires in the next few decades given recent high temperatures.

The past droughts and temperature changes produced rapid swings in the amount of forest cover at high elevation, and in combination with the large Medieval fires, rapidly transformed the landscape of northern Colorado. Many areas of forest never recovered from fires because the growing conditions that existed after the fires differed from those that had existed before. As a result, some types of new sub-alpine forests only developed after the Medieval fires and have little fossil evidence of having existed before hand. Recent changes in growing conditions may similarly shape the patterns of forest regrowth after the mountain pine beetle outbreak and recent wildfires. If the Medieval period provides a precedent for the future, novel forest types and landscape vegetation patterns unlike those found before may emerge as plants regrow after recent and future disturbances.

The projects and their outcomes have enabled Shuman to bring a new perspective about the geography of water, ecosystems, and natural resources to classes at the University of Wyoming. For example, new related units were developed for a course for future K-12 teachers, which typically reaches 40 students each spring. Likewise, Shuman has used the material in presentations to public audiences across the state of Wyoming. Ultimately, the class materials and presentations have sparked new interest in STEM in Wyoming undergraduates who have, in turn, become involved in the field and lab research. At least five undergraduates involved have gone on to graduate degrees and careers related to natural resources.
